answer_html: \(c=1 < \infty.\) So \(c\) is positive and finite. Therefore, by the limit comparison test, the sum \({\color{blue}\sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} -k}}\) converges.
answer_latex:
$c=1 < \infty.$  So $c$ is positive and finite. Therefore, by the limit
comparison test, the sum
${\color{blue}\sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} -k}}$
converges.
hints_html:
Try using the limit comparison test. You may also want to remind yourself of the p-series test.

Consider the dominant powers in the numerator and denominator of the terms in the series when determining a series to compare to when using the limit comparison test.

hints_raw:
Try using the <b>limit comparison test</b>. You may also want to remind yourself of the <b>p-series test</b>.
Consider the dominant powers in the numerator and denominator of the terms in the series when determining a series to compare to when using the limit comparison test.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
For this question, we apply the limit comparision test. Let

\[\begin{aligned} a_{k} = \frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} - k}.\end{aligned}\]

We wish to define another series \(\sum b_{k}\) such that

\[\begin{aligned} c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{a_{k}}{b_{k}}\end{aligned}\]

is positive and finite (i.e. \(< \infty\)). By comparing the dominant powers in the numerator (1/3) and denominator (2), we are inspired (1/3-2 = -5/3) to define \(b_{k}\) as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_{k} = k^{-5/3} = \frac1{k^{5/3}}.\end{aligned}\]

The terms \(a_{k}\), \(b_{k}\) are positive for all \(k \ge 2\). By the limit comparison test, if \(c\) is positive and finite, then both series converge or both diverge. We can see that \(\displaystyle \sum_{k} b_{k}\) will converge by the p-series test, since the power on \(k\) in the denominator, \(5/3\), is greater than \(1\). So if \(c\) is finite, then \(\displaystyle \sum_{k}a_{k}\) converges.

\[\begin{aligned} c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}\times k^{5/3}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{k^{2}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{1}{1 - 1/k} = 1 < \infty.\end{aligned}\]

So \(c\) is positive and finite. Therefore, by the limit comparison test, the sum \({\color{blue}\sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} -k}}\) converges.

For this question, we apply the limit comparision test. Let

\begin{align*}
a_{k} = \frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} - k}.
\end{align*} We wish to define another
series $\sum b_{k}$ such that

\begin{align*}
c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{a_{k}}{b_{k}}
\end{align*} is positive and
finite (i.e. $< \infty$). By comparing the dominant powers in the
numerator \emph{(1/3)} and denominator \emph{(2)}, we are inspired
\emph{(1/3-2 = -5/3)} to define $b_{k}$ as

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
b_{k} = k^{-5/3} = \frac1{k^{5/3}}.
\end{align*} The terms $a_{k}$, $b_{k}$ are
positive for all $k \ge 2$. By the limit comparison test, if $c$ is
positive and finite, then both series converge or both diverge. We can
see that $\displaystyle \sum_{k} b_{k}$ will converge by the p-series
test, since the power on $k$ in the denominator, $5/3$, is greater than
$1$. So if $c$ is finite, then $\displaystyle \sum_{k}a_{k}$ converges.

\begin{align*}
c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}\times k^{5/3}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{k^{2}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{1}{1 - 1/k} = 1 < \infty.
\end{align*} So $c$ is positive and finite. Therefore, by the limit
comparison test, the sum
${\color{blue}\sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} -k}}$
converges.
sols_raw:
For this question, we apply <b>the limit comparision test</b>. Let
:<math>
a_{k} = \frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} - k}.
</math>
We wish to define another series <math>\sum b_{k}</math> such that 
:<math>
c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{a_{k}}{b_{k}}
</math>
is positive and finite (i.e. <math>< \infty</math>). By comparing the dominant powers in the numerator ''(1/3)'' and denominator ''(2)'', we are inspired ''(1/3-2 = -5/3)'' to define <math>b_{k}</math> as
:<math> \displaystyle
b_{k} = k^{-5/3} = \frac1{k^{5/3}}.
</math>
The terms <math>a_{k}</math>, <math>b_{k}</math> are positive for all <math>k \ge 2</math>. By the limit comparison test, if <math>c</math> is positive and finite, then both series converge or both diverge. We can see that <math>\displaystyle\sum_{k} b_{k}</math> will converge by the <b>p-series test</b>, since the power on <math>k</math> in the denominator, <math>5/3</math>, is greater than <math>1</math>. So if <math>c</math> is finite, then <math>\displaystyle\sum_{k}a_{k}</math> converges.
:<math>
\begin{align}
c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}\times k^{5/3}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{k^{2}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{1}{1 - 1/k} = 1 < \infty.
\end{align}
</math>
So <math>c</math> is positive and finite. <font style="color:blue;">Therefore, by the limit comparison test, the sum <math>{\color{blue}\sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} - k}}</math> converges.</font>
statement_html:
This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, find out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justification in order to receive credit.

(a)

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} - k}\,.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, find out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justification in order to receive credit.

'''(a)'''
:<math>
\sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} - k}\,.
</math>
